subject: Re: Quikscript for German?
msgSnippet: Tack så mycket, det är mycket interessant. Jag skal experimentera med dina förslag som tycks vara utmärkt! Först havde jag tänkt att placera en punkt
messageBody:
Tack så mycket, det är mycket interessant. Jag skal experimentera med
dina förslag som tycks vara utmärkt! Först havde jag tänkt att placera
en punkt under de givna teckena för det engliska språket för våga
"umlauterna", men din idé är bättre.

Hälsningar till Sverige,

Hermann



--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, Benct Philip Jonsson <bpj@...>
wrote:
>
> Hermann Philipps skrev:
> > Hi,
> >
> > I'm new to this group and not totally informed of everything that has
> > been delt with here.
> > Does anyone know of an adaptation of Quikscript to the German
> > language? On the whole, Quikscript works quite well for German.
> > However, we have those umlaut letters (äöü) in short and long
> > pronunciation. Any ideas?
> >
> > Greetings,
> > Hermann
> >
>
> I have experimented quite a lot with adapting QS to Swedish,
> and have found it necessary to reshuffle the values of the
> vowel letters quite a lot. I almost ran out of letters, saving
> the day only by assigning #18 and #20 to long and short
> Swedish _y_, and by inventing a 'long' counterpart of #38
> looking like a combination of the counterclockwise version
> of #36 + #31, which works only because #31 is assigned to _a_
> and #31 to long _ä_, and these two vowels dont really occur in
> succession. Swedish has one pair of long/short vowel more than
> German, but OTOH German has its three diphthongs _ei au eu_
> which need their signs beside the eight pairs of long/short
> vowels. So in sum German needs 19 vowel letters while Swedish
> needs only 18. Maybee you could skip the _e/ä_ distinction
> which carries no great functional load in German -- at least
> short _e/ä_ being not distinguished at all for the vast majority
> of speakers.
>
> My vowel letter assignments are as follows, taking into consideration
> both the frequency of the vowel sounds in Swedish text -- wanting
> to assign the simplest signs to the most frequent vowels -- *and*
> trying not to stray too far from the English values at least for the
> short vowels:
>
> Short Long
>
> i #26 #27
> e #28 #29
> ä #30 #31
> ö #32 #33
> å (o) #34 #35
> a #36 #37
> o (u) #38 #36+#31
> u (ü) #39 #40
> y #18 #20
>
> Corresponding German sound values are in parentheses.
> In actuality it is Swedish _y_ that corresponds to
> German _ü_, while Swedish _u_ is a sound intermediate
> between _y, ö, u_ (a roundedf central vowel for the
> phonetically inclined).
>
> I'd suggest the following assignments for German:
>
> Short Long
>
> i #26 #27
> e/ä #28 #29
> ö #30 #31
> o #34 #35
> a #36 #37
> u #39 #40
> ü #18 #20
> ei/ai #32
> eu/äu #33
> au #38
>
> The reassignment of _ö_ compared to Swedish is
> because of the high frequency of _ö_ in German,
> which makes it more convenient to assign to a
> simpler sign.
>
> Since Swedish _j_ unlike the English /j/ ('y') can
> occur in any position in the word, notably at the
> end of a word after any (short) vowel QS #17 is not
> suitable for this sound, so I used #14, which has no
> counterpart in Swedish, for _j_ instead. While German
> doesn't need this particular reassignment it does need
> a better sign for its _ch_ sounds than the QS 'Loch'
> letter, which isn't suitable for fast writing, so I'd
> suggest using #14 for German _ch_ instead.
>
> Also German needs a letter for _z_ ('ts'); the best choice
> is probably #7. Preferably there should also be a
> letter for _pf_, even though many speakers merge it with
> _f/v_; I dare not suggest #8 for _pf_, so probably the
> Senior QS abbreviated #1 + #9 is the best choice. Of
> course German _f/_ and _v_ should both be written with
> #9 and german _w_ with #10, and finally #12 for single
> _s_ and #11 for _ss/ß_, and silent _h_ is of course not
> to be written! At least German QS writers won't have to
> argue over the German TO reform! :-)
>
> --
> /BP 8^)>
> --
> Benct Philip Jonsson -- melroch at melroch dot se
>
> "Maybe" is a strange word. When mum or dad says it
> it means "yes", but when my big brothers say it it
> means "no"!
>
> (Philip Jonsson jr, age 7)
>
